stories.title: New Zealander killed in cycling accident on 'Death Road' in Bolivia
stories.alt_headline: Kiwi dies on Death Road in Bolivia
stories.intro: A New Zealander has died in Bolivia in a mountain bike accident on one of the world's most dangerous roads.
stories.alt_intro: The man was in a cycling accident on one of the world's most dangerous roads when he slipped over the edge.
stories.body:
A New Zealander has died in Bolivia in a mountain bike accident on one of the world's most dangerous roads. 

The accident happened on the notorious Yungas highway from La Paz to Coroico, commonly known as "Death Road," at about 11:50am Bolivian time on January 22 (6:50pm January 23 NZT).

He was on a guided tour with Gravity Assisted Mountain Biking Bolivia, a company owned and founded by fellow New Zealander Alistair Matthews, who is now based in Nelson. 

In a statement, Matthews said: "All of us at Gravity Bolivia are deeply shaken by this tragic accident and want to express our deepest condolences to his friends and family."

READ MORE:
* Kiwi mountainbiker who conquered the "Road of Death" returns home

The guided ride is a 64km distance, with a vertical descent of 3600m, the equivalent of Mt Cook to sea level. The first 20km are paved asphalt but then turns into a single lane dirt road with significant cliff-side drops. 

The group is believed to have been made up of 12 riders, plus two guides and a support vehicle. 

According to Matthews, the ride is broken up into 12 or 13 sections of up to 5km each.

Guides were made aware of the accident after the man did not arrive at one of the prescribed stops, at which point they rode back up the road and identified where he had fallen off the road. 

The lead guide abseiled down to where he had fallen, about 100 metres below the road, and determined that there was no sign of life. 

The man's body has been since recovered with the help of local authorities. 

Matthews said that the conditions had been wet, but not out of the ordinary. 

"It had been raining, and the rain had just begun to pick up at the time, but I wouldn't say it was torrential. That would be fairly typical conditions at this time of year."

Another New Zealand woman, who was travelling with the man, also sustained facial injuries, though Matthews confirmed that they were sustained around 20 minutes prior, in a separate incident.

She crashed on the road but did not go over the edge. 

She is currently hospital in La Paz. 

Matthews said that Gravity Bolivia, which was established in 1998 and was the first company to offer cycle tours of the road, had served over 100,000 customers and this was the first death they had ever had due to accident or crash. 

They had previously had one other customer die on the road, who Matthews said was an "older American gentleman", after he suffered a heart attack. 

There were about 30 companies offering cycle tours of the road, and he estimated there had been about 30 deaths on the road since 1998.

"It almost seems ridiculous in this day and age, but it's one of those things where it's not clear, but it's probably around 30. Bolivia being Bolivia, some businesses pay to have these things vanished."

He said that he had attempted to pass a minimum safety standard regulation across all tour operators, but it was never implemented due to "considerable resistance from some companies."

He said Gravity Bolivia was going through an investigation to determine that their safety standards were up to scratch said he was "confident" in their quality. 

A Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade spokesperson said they were aware of the death and were providing consular support to his partner and family. MFAT would not provide any details on the incident, citing privacy reasons.

images.caption: The notorious Bolivian road commonly named "Death Road".
The Kiwi man was believed to be killed on the notorious Yungas highway, which stretches from La Paz to Coroico.
Yungas Road, commonly known as "Death Road," one of the world's most dangerous roads.
It's understood the man died while travelling in Bolivia.

stories.title: Images of Cape Kidnappers rock fall emerge
stories.intro: Dramatic new photos of the rockfall at Cape Kidnappers have come to light.
stories.alt_intro: Series of images captures the moment cliff collapsed, injuring two people.
stories.body:
Dramatic new photos of the rockfall at Cape Kidnappers have come to light.

The series of photographs has been supplied by Gannet Safaris Overland, which travels to the cape on a track above the cliffs. One of their passengers captured the images.

Two other people walking along the beach were injured when the rockfall occurred. 

They were flown by rescue helicopter to Hawke's Bay Hospital.

READ MORE:
* Two hurt, one critically in dramatic seaside landslide near Clifton, Hawke's Bay
* Children rescued after being washed out to sea
* Rescue device saving time and lives at sea
* Stranded fisher helped to safety by searchers

A woman aged in her 20s remains in a critical condition. A man, also in his 20s, is in a stable condition.

The tour group had coincidentally stopped to take photographs of the beach just seconds before the rock fall occurred at 2.30pm.

The first image shows the debris of a rockfall that occurred the previous day.

The tractor and trailer of the Gannet Beach Adventures can be seen on the Clifton side of the rockfall. 

The guide had stopped at that point and guided his 47 passengers over the rockfall. They were walking between the rockfall and the cape, and were a long way away when it occurred.

A Hastings District Council spokeswoman said beach access from Clifton to Cape Kidnappers remained closed to vehicles and pedestrians until further notice and the public were "strongly advised to keep away from this area until further notice".

"Agencies are urgently coordinating geotech expertise from around NZ who can access the area in order to inform next steps. This is expected to begin late this afternoon," she said.

"Until this geotech assessment has been completed the beach access to Cape Kidnappers will remain closed".

The images were supplied Gannet Safaris Overland.

The overland trips have not been disrupted by the fall and are still running.

images.caption: Image captures the moment a cliff collapsed at Cape Kidnappers.
Images taken of Cape Kidnappers rockfall by a passenger on the Gannet Safaris Overland trip.
Beach access from Clifton to Cape Kidnappers remains closed to vehicles and pedestrians until further notice

videos.caption: A tourist was in the right place at the right time to snap these dramatic images of the Cape Kidnappers rock fall.

stories.title: Man charged with Takapuna Beach 'car attack' on woman has identity suppressed
stories.intro: A man charged with assault and reckless driving after an incident at Auckland's Takapuna Beach has appeared in court.
stories.alt_intro: Man charged with assaulting woman with car has name kept secret.
stories.body:
A man charged with assault and reckless driving after an incident at Auckland's Takapuna Beach has appeared in court. 

The man is alleged to have assaulted a woman using a car as a weapon on January 13.

He is also alleged to have used a vehicle recklessly on Hurstmere Rd, Takapuna.

The man appeared on Thursday at the Auckland District Court in front of Community Magistrate Jan Holmes.

Holmes granted interim name suppression for the man and also suppressed all details that could identify him.

A police spokesman said officers were still investigating the alleged incident involving a car on the city's North Shore.

The maximum penalty for an assault using a car is five years in prison, while the reckless driving charge carries a sentence of up to three months in prison and a $4500 fine.

The man was remanded in custody until his next appearance in court on Friday.

images.caption: A man has been charged after an incident at Takapuna Beach on January 13 (file photo).
The man appeared in Auckland District Court on Thursday (file photo).

stories.title: Singaporean actor Aloysius Pang dies following military training accident in New Zealand
stories.intro: Singaporean actor Aloysius Pang has died following an accident during a military training exercise in New Zealand.
stories.alt_intro: Police are investigating the death of a Singaporean actor who died after an accident during a military training exercise in New Zealand.
stories.body:
Singaporean actor Aloysius Pang has died following an accident during a military training exercise in New Zealand. 

A police spokesman said the death was being investigated on behalf of the coroner.

The 28-year-old actor sustained serious injuries to his chest and abdomen on Saturday while carrying out repairs inside a Singapore self-propelled Howitzer at the Waiouru training area, south of Taupō.

Pang was taken to Waikato Hospital, where Dr Teo Li Tserng, Chief of Trauma and Acute Care Surgery at Singapore's Tan Tock Seng Hospital, was flown in to assist the local team.

"Despite surgical attempts to repair damaged organs and putting him on artificial life support, CFC (NS) Pang succumbed to the injuries and passed away," the Singapore Ministry of Defence said in an official statement. 

READ MORE:
* Singapore actor Aloysius Pang injured in NZ during military training
* Noisy Singapore Air Force jets irk some Sanson residents
* Huge gulf of trauma care between North & South Islands, doctors say
* Military vehicles invade downtown Auckland

An independent Committee of Inquiry will be convened to investigate the circumstances leading to the incident.

Pang's family shared their grief on his Instagram account this morning, writing: "Throughout the past few days in the hospital, it has been a difficult time for us. Every news that were brought upon us since his last op was devastating, with little signs of hope on his recovery."

"We all broke down when the medical team spoke to us that his condition is worsening and we should be prepared for the worst. We're going to lose a brother. And my parents are going to lose their precious son whom is only 28. Thus I seek everybody's kind understanding that we are unable to comment further during these precarious time."

 
 
 
 
View this post on Instagram
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

On behalf of our family Throughout the past few days in the hospital, it has been a difficult time for us. Every news that were brought upon us since his last op was devastating with little signs of hope on his recovery. We all broke down when the medical team spoke to us that his condition is worsening and we should be prepared for the worst. We're going to lose a brother. And my parents are going to lose their precious son whom is only 28. Thus I seek everybody's kind understanding that we are unable to comment further during these precarious time.

A post shared by 冯伟衷 Aloysius Pang (@aloypang) on Jan 23, 2019 at 7:35am PST

Pang was doing repairs inside the Howitzer, a motorised piece of artillery that looks similar to a small tank, when he was injured, the ministry said.

The New Zealand Defence Force said its soldiers were not involved when the incident occurred.

"The soldier was taking part in Exercise Thunder Warrior which is an annual live-firing exercise held in Waiouru," a Defence spokeswoman said.

"The New Zealand Defence Force hosts Exercise Thunder Warrior and provides administrative support and liaison officers but was not taking part in this year's exercise."

A medical officer at Waiouru assessed him around 2:30pm on Saturday, before he was sent to the Waiouru Camp Medical Centre for further treatment.

By 4:10pm, the Singapore Defence Ministry said a helicopter had arrived to take Pang to hospital, where he spent more than five and a half hours in surgery. 

The Singapore Armed Forces was making arrangements to have his body brought back home.

Pang was known for his work in the films Young & Fabulous, Timeless Love, and an assortment of TV series.

images.caption: Aloysius Pang has died while training in New Zealand.
Aloysius Pang won Best Newcomer at the 2015 Star Awards, held annually in Singapore.

stories.title: ERA awards nearly $30,000 for unjustified dismissal and loss of dignity
stories.intro: A Christchurch man has been awarded nearly $30,000 for unjustified dismissal after he was sacked for sharing details of his salary with a co-worker.
stories.alt_intro: Builder's employee awarded $30k after being fired for talking pay rates with a co-worker.
stories.body:
A Christchurch man has been awarded nearly $30,000 for unjustified dismissal after he was sacked for sharing details of his salary with a co-worker.

An Employment Relations Authority (ERA) decision found James Luhrs was hired in June 2017 as a salesman for Whitehouse Builders, a Christchurch building firm, along two other sales staff.

Luhrs claimed he was unjustifiably dismissed in October 2017 by founder Robert Whitehouse.

READ MORE:
* Relief teacher's ERA reinstatement bid fails
* Dismissal of Timaru McDonald's worker who was too slow justified
* Work To Rule: $13k compo for nine days' work

During salary negotiations, Whitehouse agreed to pay Luhrs a base salary of $50,000 with commission, $10,000 more than he was paying the other sales staff.

He asked Luhrs not tell the other staff he was being paid more.

After less than a month on the job, Luhrs' salary was suddenly reduced to $40,000 and he was told he would now work part-time.

Whitehouse said that despite investing considerable time training Luhrs he was dissatisfied with his performance, and that he seemed distracted by his own home build project.

Luhrs claimed because he was still within the 90-day probationary period he only reluctantly agreed to have his pay reduced. 

Later that year Luhrs and a colleague were having a drink after work, and Luhrs reportedly asked the co-worker if it was legal for Whitehouse to have reduced his base salary from $50,000 to $40,000. 

The following day the co-worker confronted Whitehouse about the discrepancy in salaries and afterwards, resigned.

Whitehouse then confronted Luhrs, which resulted in his dismissal, with Luhrs asked to leave the property. 

Whitehouse claimed he had not dismissed Luhrs, but had told him to go so that there was some space for them both to cool off.

Howeve, the ERA agreed with Luhrs that he had been dismissed, unjustifiably.

It found Luhrs was unjustifiably dismissed and suffered an unjustifiable disadvantage in his employment by having had his pay reduced unilaterally, and was entitled to a payout.

Luhrs was awarded $28,630, after a 30 per cent discount was applied due to Luhrs breaching good faith by revealing his salary.

images.caption: Robert Whitehouse, owner of Whitehouse Builders claimed he had not dismissed Luhrs, but had told him to go so that there was some space for them both to cool off.
James Luhrs was sacked for sharing the details of his salary with a colleague.
